within the 4th and the double Sodium 
line (Na) within the 14th of these bands. 
Under favourable circumstances - both 
extremities of the spectrum being equally 
developed - these bands extend to the 
channeled part, <s>of<\s> their number rising 
to 35. All have the same general cha 
racter, but not the same brightness. From 
the extreme red the intensity of light increases 
to the 8th band, over the 9th, 10th, and 11th,
especially over the last two ones a shadow 
is spread, which gives to the red a rather 
brownish tint. The next seven bands are 
of a fine orange and yellow colour.
The 19th and 20th band[s] are very dark,
the 21th is less dark. The following bands 
have a green colour, varying in brightness.
The darkest are the 28th and 29th, succeeding 
to the lightest ones.
The cause producing these bands and their 
shading by dark transverse lines is evi 
dently not the same as that which pro 
duces the shadow overspreading some 
of them. <u>It <\u> [This] may be for instance con
cluded from the fact, that the shadow 
which darkens the 19th, and the 20th band, without 
entirely destroying their limits, spreads 
at the same time over the neighbouring 
third part of the preceeding 18th band.
